Award.AwardTitle: Geochemical Characterization of Prince William Sound and Copper River Sediments: A Proxy Development to Assess Climate-Driven Variations in a High-Resolution Sedimentary Record
Award.AbstractNarration:
As part of a two-year postdoctoral research fellowship, this project focuses on determining the elemental composition of Prince William Sound (PWS) and Copper River sediments by analyzing a time-series throughout varying environmental conditions. These data will be used to interpret preserved sedimentary signatures contained within cores whose record extends into the last century, the period for which relatively robust instrumental records of discharge, climate, and oceanographic conditions exist. Ultimately, it is hoped the results of this research will allow high-resolution characterization of climatic drivers over the last several millennia. This knowledge will further understanding of how this system has responded in the past, and may provide crucial predictive information concerning future climate variations. Additionally, a key outreach component for this study is the development of a teaching curriculum to be used by underserved populations within rural Alaska who have limited access to science education or current research. The program will aim to further student understanding of how scientists use sediment cores to identify climate trends in PWS and the northern Pacific Ocean, and the subsequent impact on fisheries distribution, subsistence, and commercial harvests. This project will be conducted under the mentorship of Dr. Steven A. Kuehl at the Virginia Institute of Marine Science.

The PWS is a sensitive sub-arctic region where rapidly changing climate patterns strongly alter hydrological and oceanographic conditions in ways that have profound ecological and economical implications. This research seeks to exploit the potential for a high-resolution environmental record contained within PWS sediment, which may allow us to understand changing river sediment dispersal and/or climate-driven oceanographic patterns throughout the Holocene. Previous X-ray Fluorescence (XRF) analyses reveal that PWS sediment cores contain geochemical and sedimentological signatures that can potentially resolve varying source input. Elemental ratios (e.g. Sr/Mn, Zn/S, K/Ca) may provide a basis for differentiating Chugach/northern PWS derived sediment loads from those of the upper Copper River. However, there is a paucity of information on compositional variations within the major drainage basins, and understanding seasonal variability influenced by changing provenance/ freshwater sources (e.g., snow melt, glacial melt, and rainfall, Chugach vs. Wrangell Range) in Copper River discharge is critical for the development of environmental proxy records. Once constrained, these proxies have the potential to resolve climatic oscillations on sub-annual to decadal timescales. Therefore, this project focuses on collecting a high-resolution time-series of representative samples of PWS and Copper River basin sediments with the aim to confidently constrain elemental variations observed in sediment core XRF records. Elemental composition of suspended sediment concentrations will be determined using Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICPMS). Samples will also be analyzed for cosmogenic 7Be to test the hypothesis that the ubiquitously used tracer for recent fluvial sedimentation may be problematic in high latitude settings during spring discharge/ glacial melt.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overall, the objective of this study was to determine the temporal variability in Copper River (CR), Alaska suspended sediment geochemical signature in order to better understand the recent sedimentary record within Prince William Sound (PWS), which is the primary repository for CR sediments. The primary goal being to develop and constrain proxies (“fingerprints”) that allow identification of CR sediments throughout the northern Gulf of Alaska (GoA) and PWS. This sub-arctic region has been shown to be sensitive to changes in climate patterns that determine the amount and timing of river discharge, glacial retreat/advance, and ocean wave conditions. Ultimately, these processes determine how much sediment is delivered to PWS, where it is sourced from, and the signature preserved once it accumulates on the seafloor. Combined, the multiple sediment sources of the region have amassed a phenomenally thick (>150 m) late-Holocene (3500-4000 years before present) sedimentary record within PWS, providing potential sub-annual resolution insight to the amalgam of these processes.

One key outcome of this project was the development and constraint of sediment provenance signatures, particularly from the Copper River, that may be utilized in current and future studies of the PWS sedimentary record. This proxy development was critical in order to assess the high-resolution geochemical variations observed in sediment cores. These signatures have resulted in identification and differentiation of riverine and glacial sediment input. We have demonstrated that these provenance signatures are significantly different between the CR and PWS basins, and additionally that changing freshwater/sediment provenance (e.g., snow melt, glacial melt, and rainfall, Chugach/upper vs. Wrangell/lower Range/drainage basin) in CR discharge is discernable. Additionally, we have provided highly resolved particulate nitrogen and organic carbon flux measurements to the GoA, which considering the CR is the single largest source of freshwater and sediment to this region, provides valuable information regarding the biogeochemical cycling of these compounds. Additionally, the geochemical signatures identified in this study have been used to identify several earthquake triggered sediment gravity flows within PWS that leave distinctive sedimentary deposits. The marine paleoseismic record identified here is a vital tool for seismological studies, capturing most large earthquakes which occurred within the CR/PWS region with corresponding deposits. This indicates that the sedimentary record is relatively complete, and the proxies developed in this project may be utilized to characterize late-Holocene seismic activity. Another significant outcome of this study is the novel time-series measurement of 7Be activity within fluvial suspended sediments of a major high-yield sub-arctic river, leading to a potential paradigm shift in the way this cosmogenic produced tracer is utilized in quantifying event and seasonal sedimentation along continental margins.

Also, a significant outcome of this project was the development and dissemination of educational materials. A curricula aimed at middle-high school students was developed with the focus of understanding what the sedimentary record can tell us about Earth history, using the some of the research conducted during this project within PWS as an example. The lesson teaches basic concepts of geology and oceanography, and delves into sediment sources of the region (Copper River, glaciers, etc.), how transport processes can leave distinct sediment features, and how these events can occur seasonally (such as summer versus winter river discharge) or discretely (earthquake). The activity has multimedia resources for the lecture section, and a hands-on activity that involves students taking “cores” with distinctive layering that they then subsequently use to interpret the “sediment” record. The materials necessary for the activity are easily accessible (can buy at any grocery store) and inexpensive (less than $10). The full lesson will remain available for free to any interested educator and has already been implemented into schools in both Alaska and Virginia and summer educational programs. This lesson continues to be highly impactful as many of the rural communities serviced through these outlets are comprised of largely underrepresented groups with limited access to science education and current research.
